I was sitting around the kitchen table wondering how I could model a playground slide, or those water slide tubes.
This thing adds hermite curve/surface support to the OpenScad Surface Solids library.
The basic Hermite interpolation calculation has actually been lurking for a while, but now it's put to good usage.  With this, there is now a lerp (linear interpolation), berp (bezier interpolation), and herp (hermite interpolation) in the library.
A Hermite curve is defined by two endpoints, and the tangent vectors to those points.  It is somewhat related to a Bezier curve.  In fact, I use the same Bernstein basis functions to express it.  Some people may find it easier to deal with, some harder, but it's just another tool in the box to help you create surfaces.
In this particular case, I've added a 'sweep_hermite()' module to the renderer.  This is really easy to work with.  You define one curve to be your 'profile', and you define another curve to be the path along which you'll sweep that profile.  The module will take care of creating the appropriate polyhedra to fill in the solid.  You can give a thickness, and it will extrude in that direction.  This is similar to the linear_extrude.
This also shows a general mechanism for doing sweeps with curves.  To make it fully generalized, and to reduce the amount of code needed to support different curves, I'll be further developing the matrix representation of curves.  That will essentially be the same as having function pointers for surface creation, if you catch my drift.
I've added some visual debugging support.  If you decide to show the control frame, you'll get a nice rendering of the profile and sweeep curves, complete with their tangent vectors.
Using tangent vectors is interesting.  You need to be mindful that a vector has a length and direction.  The length influences the strength of pull in the particular direction.  It's best if you think of them centered at [0,0,0] and point them in the direction you want them to go.  You'll have to play around with setting them to get the gist of it.
It occurs to me that this might be a good tool to use while learning about different types of curves and surfaces.  Particularly with the visual debugging, and the added bonus that you get to print out a physical thing after you've done all your hard playing around.
I made the license public domain, as this is well trod ground.
Are Splines in the offing?
At any rate...

1) Download the .scad files
2) Play around with the test_hermite.scad to make pretty pictures
3) Compile and export to .stl
4) Rejoice! In most cases, it will generate a solid surface which can be turned into a .stl file. The most likely usage here is to generate singular pieces that are stuck together with other pieces. Like my water slide shutes.

title: Creatr HS flex filament adapter - No need to drill

description.text: I added larger holes to eliminate the need to drill. Just print it out, screw in the attachment, and install it in your printer. The original Thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724928) has pictures to help figure out how to install it.

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724928 for pictures that show where this goes in the printer. Just unscrew the little black screw to take the old part out, and replace it with this new part.

To get the attachment to screw in, I held the adapter with a pair of pliers and screwed the attachment in using a wrench. It was pretty easy, just make sure that it goes in straight.

I have printed successfully in both PLA and ABS, using 0.1 mm z height and 2 outer perimeters, but it should work with less resolution as well.

Really simple parts to keep spools centered on the plate in the Creatr HS. I had noticed that with some softer filaments, the spool would get pulled to one side, which could screw up the print as the filament would no longer feed correctly. This simple Thing fixes that problem.

Unfortunately, this will only work on the right side for larger spools (colorFabb, Matterhackers, etc), as the left side does not have enough room, but for smaller spools (Taulman, etc) it will work on both sides.

It is designed for spools with a 50-55 mm inner diameter (which is all the spools I have found and use).

This Thing is actually larger than it needs to be, I ended up stopping the print about half way through and it still works like a charm.

No need for high resolution. I printed this on the fastest settings with the lowest resolution I could, and only 10% infill. Could probably even do less infill.

After printing it out, simply put it on the metal spool holder already in the printer, and it should keep your filament spools centered.

A simple vent with internal damper for a smoke machine, made to fit behind a panel where a previous installation was just a collection of random PVC fittings, hoses and massive amounts of duct tape. The output flange is 5" across and has an extra wide lip for mounting to the panel with VHB foam tape. The hose inlet should fit standard 1.5" rubber hose. The damper allows for almost full closure of the pipe so it can adjust flow when more than one is used on the same machine.

Edit: Flipped the vent over for better printing. No changes were done to the mesh. Added version without damper by request.
Printed with 4 shells, 0.2 layers, raft and support on a Z18. Print time for the whole assembly was approximately 14 hours.

title: XY and one-axis plates for Mini Arcade Joystick

description.text: First is a 4-way limiting plate to make the 8-way mini arcade joystick sold by Adafruit (http://adafruit.com/products/480) and others into a 4-way (X-Y axis) joystick. The other one is a 2-way (one axis) plate for playing games that only require one axis of motion. It's either X or Y, depending on which set of mounting holes you use. Since it has switches instead of pots, this joystick will work easily with picoboards and other controls for games made in Scratch. Also see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:109795 for a printable box for this same model joystick!

We're the 3D print for a cure type! These designs are based on the new JDRF OneWalk logo, ready to be made for you and your team. The designs are very similar -- rectangle, and two rounded versions.

For more information about the JDRF OneWalk: http://www2.jdrf.org/site/PageServer?pagename=walk_homepage

To donate to my family's team: http://goo.gl/58N9na

Note: Although I am a volunteer on a local JDRF board, there is no endorsement of this design by JDRF.

How I printed the rectangular version, on a MakerBot Replicator 2:

X=100, Y=25

Base (white): 0% - 67%
Line (black) 67% - 83% (After OneWalk, there is one more pass on
the black)
OneWalk (orange) 83% - 91%
JDRF (blue): 91% - 100%

(About 40 minutes)

How I printed the "Rounded 2" version:
x = 80, Y = 30.13 version

Base (white): 0% - 69% or so
Line (black) 69% - 84% (After OneWalk, there is one more pass on
the black)
OneWalk (orange) 84% - 92%
JDRF (blue): 92% - 100%

(About 25 minutes)

title: Back Tripod Mount for iPads with Cases

description.text: This design works with the front mount of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:827169. I redesigned the part to work with iPADs that had cases. This design works with iPad Minis in Portrait and Landscape recording.

I changed add blocks to the top and side to to be able to hold a tablet with a case. An iPad with a case needed more side support to hold the tablet. A case needs to be pressed on the outside to hold the tablet firm. Our iPads fell out out of the original design. We printed the mounts at 50% fill and 2 shells to take the roughness to some users will treat the print.

description.text: This is a printable version of the hammers which can be seen during "Waiting For The Worms" in the movie "The Wall" from Pink Floyd. I split the hammer head in three parts for better printability. There is also a split-up version of the handle so that you can print the parts in the correct colour. Let me know if there is a flaw in the design or if there is something I can improve.

If you have a FFF (fused filament fabrication) printer, it's best to print the split-up head. Depending on whether you have the right colours you can print the handle in parts or just in one go. When you have all the parts you can stick and glue the parts together.

Someone broke a coworkers coffee cup handle (and threw away the pieces). The cup had a sentimental value as it was given to him by his wife with pictures of his wife and child on the cup. In short, he still wanted to use the cup.

So I designed a holder and a handle that is rugged enough to easily hold the weight of the cup including coffee.

Print it out.
I used a height of 0.4 mm.
Then I added some rubber adhesive pads to make the fit tight and put the handle on the holder.
Then add a 3mm screw with mother.

Another apple watch battery recharging base, but this time a very easy to carry with you one. I was playing with my designs looking for something small that can be easy setup and hold the watch in a nice position. The support is very portable, but this is not necessary the good point, because the battery duration, in my case, is good enough for all day around. It is really a very easy to put away in any other place when not in use. You can accommodate it even in you pocket if you want without feel any uncomfortable. It do not need any additional hardware, just print it, clean any unwanted debris and assemble the two parts together and you are ready to use it.

I test is with 42mm and 38mm watch models and it works fine. I do not have any metal watch band, only sport silicone and some leather pieces which cause me no problem holding the watch on the base for recharge the battery.

I added the new stl file without the letters "apple watch". I found them do not print as good as I like. You can try any one of them.

In my case, I have good results using .25mm layers height with no support. I prefer to use brim to minimize any distortion. The base stl file may need it and also rotate 180 degrees.

To assemble it, just clean any PLA debris on the rotation shaft and cover holes notches then, insert the two pieces together. It close very firmly, and I prefer to open it using my two thumbs while holding it with my other fingers from the battery charger slot. Pushing from behind works better than pulling from the front.

comments.text: I travel a lot and wanted a small stand - this one is perfect!  I've already printed 3 of these so far to give as Christmas gifts for family.  I tried to send you a tip but it said you are not set up to receive tips.  Thank you for creating and sharing this file!

remixed_from.title: Pill Bottle Organizer for Tool Board

description.text:
This is a set of components that can be used to make variable size and shape racks for holding pill bottles(33mm diameter) full of small parts.

I looked at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:564108 and decided I needed more flexibility and heft.

Also looked at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275326 which took up more liner space than I had.

UPDATE: Mounting brackets fit into either cores or edges and has a screw-hole for securing it to walls etc.

I started by printing the 4 corners (holds 1 bottle).
Then printed a core and 2 pairs of edges. Each row needs one of each edge type. (2x2).
From there print a pair of edges and a core to add 3 bottles until you reach your desired width.
Then print a pair of edges and the appropriate number of cores.
Scale till your bench is clean.

I finally had a chance to revisit this design and make some sweet improvements. Now it tilts at the middle, so it can be used as a mini tripod on whatever surface is available. The main camera mount has slider capability to allow balance adjustment +/- 15mm. I made the base much more stable and added little feet for non flat surfaces.
It is a valuable run-and-gun tool for documentary or guerrilla filmmaking using 4/3s size cameras. The lenscap stowage in the base is another great feature. I included versions without the gopro as well. This design specifically accommodates cameras that load memory and/or battery from the bottom.
Please post your makes. Enjoy!

These are the parts you will need:
4 1/4" #6 machine screws
1 1/2" long 1/4-20 hex bolt
1 3/4" or 7/8" long 1/4-20 socket bolt
1 1/4" locknut
1 1/4-20 standard nut
Gopro nut and knob

Print the top and bottom with support. I use Simplify 3D and the support came out super easy. The foot and slider gasket are done in flex filament and are not necessary but nice to have. The feet screw in with 1/4" long #6 screws. The gasket is mounted with ca glue.
The other hardware is all 1/4-20 standard camera thread. The main camera mount uses a 1/2" long hex head bolt. Put this in before you attach the base through the hole in the swivel. The swivel itself uses a socket cap 3/4" or 7/8" long bolt and locknut.
The tripod mount in the base uses a standard 1/4-20 nut.
Measure your lenscap and pressure fit the appropriate insert into the base.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3iCjEhtvI0G

I made this because I was tired of dirt and lint getting into my flash drive. I keep one with my keys so it's in and out of my pocket all day. I printed it in ABS and smoothed it with acetone. The tip is angled to prevent snagging on the metal pins inside the USB. You could always just buy a flash drive that has a cover, but I'm cheap so I made this.

Semper Fi

I printed at .1 layer height in the upward position. I was at 100% infill with 2 perimeters. This was printed in ABS and smoothed with acetone. No need to scale for ABS prints. PLA prints may be a bit snug due to lack of shrinkage, I recommend scaling down 1% for PLA.

Small and simple LED moving head light. Design to hold discrete LED in the light and there is a guide whole to bring the cabling to the base.
Some basic gobos are included for added effect and a blank gobo is also available for you to customize. You can then shine any logo anywhere since it is battery powered.

There is sufficient space for electronic circuitry if anyone feels adventurous.

You can now see the result of my prints. I might do some tweaking here and there to improve print quality. (Like the arm could be printed lying instead of standing).

There is now a more realistic moving head wich includes servo motors.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912706

Enjoy this Thing and share the result of your prints.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Workbench

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

8%

Build of material

1 x All printed part
1 x Your selected gobo
1 x LED (or any other light source that fits)
1 x power source (either battery or external power)

Here is guide instruction to help you assemble the fixture.

  1. Print all part and prepare all electronics
  2. Glue LED to the light plug. Then glue the plug to the light.
  3. Assemble the light fixture using #4-40 screws and nuts.
  4. Pass the wiring in the guide whole
  5. Add battery to the base of the light

(Optional) Drill a whole to add a switch.

Note: You might need to orients the part for printing.

comments.text: This is really cool.  I've printed one but want to know more about the LED you use, where you placed it inside the light,
comments.author: Eddiie

comments.text:
I'm glad you like it. The light in the picture was not scaled up, there is a 6in (15 cm) ruler in front of the light for comparison.
The gobos is there for you to cut your own design/form to shine.
For the LED, in the picture I used a small LED flashlight that fitted inside the light. Since the flashlight has more then 1 LED, gobos won't work. I now use a single 1W LED and it works perfectly. Any single color LED would work, it's just a preference in how bright you want it.
I use a hotglue gun to glue the led to the light bottom plug.

Two versions (3 as of 7/29/15) of a Klein-Bottle type Hot Air Balloon, inspired by a conference logo I designed. After seeing the challenge I decided to try and make the balloon portion of my logo into a 3d model and try to create wind blades so it would spin in the wind. Whirlygig1 has thinner edges on the blades, and Whirlygig8 has thicker edges. I used some parametric equations I came up with in Mathematica to create the model and export it as a .stl file. Cleaned up some small cracks where edges meet with NetFabb (free version).
Edit: 7/29/15: Made whirlygig1 with the thin edges, and it did not turn out that well around the loop. Whirlygig8 with the thicker edges turned out much better.
I also posted an updated file: Whirlygig9 has slight modifications to the top and doesn't have the small torus/donut at the bottom of the balloon. It didn't seem that necessary with the thicker blades. I have someone printing it for me this week, so I'll try and update with a pic of whirlygig9 on Monday 8/3.
See the video of whirlygig8 here: https://youtu.be/pePyM8GfSrg
(I attached it to a fishing spinner and then to a bush branch. The branch on the bush was blowing a bit too, accounting for the up and down movement.)
Thanks to those who have "liked it" already - this is my first time posting on thingiverse - kinda fun!

I designed my model with parametric equations using Mathematica, then exported to a .stl file.
I'm trying to print them upside-down to minimize the cleanup and supports that are needed.

Tired of unscrewing spindles just to swap spools? Tired of spools with different spindle sizes? This spool holder makes changing spools easy - just set the spool on the stand. Can be printed for as many spools as you need. The pictures show a four-spool version.

The stand uses 1/2 inch diameter wooden dowels (or you could use metal). My original intent was to have the bushings turn on the dowel, but the spool plastic slides so easily on the bushings that it is not needed. If you want to add some silicon lubricant to make them turn, that 's great - they will work either way.

If you want a two-spool stand, print two ends and 8 bushings (4 bushings for each spool). Just add bushings (and longer dowels) to hold more spools.

I printed in PLA. The ends have fillets and gussets for good looks and strength. The holes for dowels are split for a firm hold on the dowels.

Also check out my filament guide (also shown in the pictures)

comments.text: I like the design. I am printing this two up on a Makerbot 2 Fifth. The problem is it is curling and lifting on the outer long edges. It is pulling the tape from the bed. I am using painters tape. The center edge is fine. This also happened on an other chinese machine printed two up with a heated bed. Does anyone know how I can stop this?

title: Raspberry Pi B+ Shell Case - Protect your Raspberry Pi while still showing off its devilishly good looks!

description.text:
This is a Shell Case for the Raspberry Pi B+ (may work with other models) that allows you to protect your Raspberry Pi without turning it into a giant block of plastic.

This Pi prints out in a top and bottom, and is secured to the Raspberry Pi by using 1.75mm 3d filament as pins (simply cut 4 small pieces from the end of your spool of plastic). This 3D printed case was tested to provide a good fit to the pins and will fit securely into any Raspberry Pi B+ model.

This case requires nothing to assemble beyond the 3D printer and filament needed to print it out.

I designed this for the reddit.com/r/3Dprinting contest for a Raspberry Pi case, and because I wanted a good looking shell that still showed off the Raspberry Pi's hardware. I 3D printed it with Inland brand Bronzefill 3d Filament from Microcenter and tested it a Raspberry Pi B+.

NOTE: Print quality on my printer is poor, hence the roughness in the pictures.

IMPORTANT PRINTING NOTE: If you intend to print the top upright using supports (which gives the best end product), make sure to change the support offset to 1mm and check it in the print preview to make sure Makerware does NOT try to print supports inside the pinholes. If supports print inside the pinholes, they will be miserable to get out. Printing with 1mm offset prevents supports from showing up inside the pinholes, but still prints supports for the Raspberry Pi logo

1. 3D print both the top and bottom pieces of the shell case
  2. Cut 4 pieces of any 1.75mm (most 3D printers use this!) filament to about 2 centimeters in length
  3. Plug all 4 pieces into the holes on the bottom piece and mount the Raspberry Pi to these 4 filament pieces
  4. Once the filament feels secure to the bottom part of the shell, measure and cut the filaments at a length of approximately 5mm or less above the surface of the Raspberry Pi
  5. Mount the top piece onto the 4 pins and push secure

title: Ball and Socket Joint - all in one print. Test object for dissolvable supports

description.text:
I was looking for an object today that would be a good application of using dissolvable supports in Simplify 3D. I didn't seen anything that interested me, so I decided to model something on my lunch hour.

It doesn't serve any particular function - even though it looks like it might. The thread on top is M8'ish - although I won't guarantee the accuracy. The clearance between the ball and the socket is exactly 0.4mm all around.

After lunch I tried to slice it in Simplify 3D, but I could not get it to generate solid support material in the gap. I had the support material resolution in S3D maxed out at 1mm (you can't go any lower).

I'd love to see if anyone else can generate solid dissolvable supports for this object and print it out.

Modeled in DesignSpark Mechanical.

I'm going to let it like this for awhile to see if anyone prints it with supports generated in their slicer.
If not, I'll create the solid support shell in a separate STL and will add it later.

comments.text: Hi, I usually design a "breakable" scaffold on the bottom and sides of the sphere of about 0.5mm in diameter. That way, it breaks easily off and for a few twists and turns you'll notice a bump but eventually it wears off and ends up nice and frictionless ...
comments.author: carlozousa

comments.text: Never mind the question I had here earlier. Thanks for all your help!
comments.author: VarshaSTEM

comments.text:
It was designed for printing with dissolvable supports. Unfortunately there is a minimum thickness required for supports, so the clearance might be a little sloppy after they were removed. The ball would not fall out though.
The other option would be to try to print it with a tighter gap and no supports. There is a high probabality you'd end up with a fused part that you could not break loose. You're welcome to try though. I just uploaded a revised version with a 0.2mm gap and much finer mesh. The ball is exactly centered in the socket so that the gap is uniform the whole way around.
Be prepared to apply a LOT of force to try to break it loose.
comments.author: KDan

comments.text:
Thank you so much! I'll try and print it with dissolvable supports but I'm not sure the printers our school has use dissolvable supports. But if they don't I can just try it with the supports our printers use instead.
Just one follow-up question -> by applying a lot of force (for the revised version) you mean force to separate the ball and the socket after printing so they aren't attached and the ball can move around in the socket, is that right? I wasn't sure if I'd read it correctly.
Thanks again!
comments.author: KDan

comments.text:
Dissolvable supports requires a dual extruder machine and a secondary support filament such as HIPS or PVA (Not PLA). I doubt that your school has that. Trying to get a slicer to place support material in there may be problematic (see my original comments).
The answer to your question is yes. The ball and socket will be at least lightly fused together. Or, they may be permanently fused together. It depends on a great many variables. Filament brand, type and composition, printing temperature, printing speed, amount of layer cooling used.
Since the revised version has 0.2mm clearance, I'd trying printing at 0.2mm layer height without supports. I'd use PLA extruded on the cool side at around 190C-195C with layer cooling fans run near maximum. I'd run a new nozzle and be certain that the filament is extruding smooth and perfectly straight out of the extruder (no curling).
Your machine needs to be capable of producing very accurately placed layers. Good luck.

author: KDan

description.text: Do you like gears? You'll like this one twice as much, since it's a double helical gear, also known as a herringbone gear. Print two of them, and flip one over. You'll notice that they mesh perfectly, and have the side benefit of self-aligning; there's no thrust produced by these gears. You can print the attached base if you want to make a toy of sorts out of it.

I printed numerous versions of this out of white and black PLA at 220 degrees, with no support. The top and bottom corners of the gear are rounded, but the angle isn't enough to need any sort of support. Since it's got very small details I would recommend a .1 slice thickness at maximum, and ideally you should print with some sort of active cooling.

This was created in AutoDesk Inventor Professional 2016, imported to AutoCad 2015, and modified to create the herringbone design and hole.

I have sized this so it will print in PLA without tweaking and fits real well, I have not tried ABS yet.
I have a FlashForge Dreamer, I used the standard setting, however I increased the outer layers from 3 to 5 and 35% infil this seems to give it adequate strength.

title: Lulzbot AO-101 spool holder for Octave 2.2 lbs

description.text: A simple holder for the Octave style 2.2 lbs spools. Use the stock hardware (bolt, washers, wingnut), replacing the stock loose filament spool.

comments.text: For those on the fence about 1.75 mm filament with the AO-101 I would not recommend it. I've now run a spool with good results but I had to slow down the printing to essentially half of what I would run with 3 mm. This is because the extruder moves much faster to feed the 1.75 mm and it tended to wad up. I had the correct size PTFE tube.
comments.author: potatoho

comments.text: Thanks for the tip, I have an AO-101 which has been having a bit of trouble with feeding 3mm, and I was pondering whether 1.75mm would make it better or worse. All info I have found indicates that switching to 1.75mm isn't going to help me, so I at least appreciate that I don't have to waste my time on it!  :)
comments.author: potatoho

comments.text: Mine began having 3mm feeding problems after a month or so of use. I think it was just a collection of issues which led to problems. I would suggest ensuring that the long filament tube is not binding. My issues were mostly when the part reached a certain height or extent, and it was exacerbated by not having a smooth path for the  filament.
comments.author: donstratton

author: vdsignsqc

description.text:
This is an adjustable-tilt light-duty mount for a Go Pro Hero2. The open top/side design makes it easy to insert and remove the camera. A clip is used to hold the open side together and provide a bit of retention force (a small beveled protusion on the inside back of the mount presses against the cam and holds it in due to friction via the clip squeezing the case together slightly).
The lens surround extends about 1mm in front of the lens forwardmost surface for front impact protection - unfortunately this makes the surround visible at the lower edges of the video at the wide FOV setting (I mainly use the narrow setting for my videos which is not an issue).
Tilt retention is via bolt/captured nut.

Print the 4 pieces out. Bond the support piece to the bottom of the case (I print primarily with ABS - I found that by smearing acetone on both surfaces and clamping them together for a few minutes results in a very strong bond). Make sure you are bonding the support piece (with the single "ear") to the case, don't bond the base piece (with the 2 "ears").
Use an M3x12 bolt and nut to secure the case/support onto the base and tighten to hold at your desired angle. Now just insert your Go Pro 2 and slide the clip down over the sides to secure it.

description.text:
Full instructions on how to build, photos, etc., can be found on my blog: http://trippingthenerdcurmudgeonly.blogspot.com/

And to see it in action!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gbky7AzVbHs

This project started back around December of 2014. I was poking around on the various 3D printing sites, looking for a printable gift for a friend’s daughter for Christmas. There were tons of M___crafty things out there, and I thought “ohhh...one of those ore nodes that has lights in it is kinda cool”. So I printed a couple, played with them, and decided it just wasn’t fancy enough.

But I’m definitely not the first.

There’s lots of them out there - most of them use LED tea lights or simple LED lights connected to coin cell batteries. In typical “Phill” fashion (as my wife likes to call it) I decided to over-engineer a solution that has way more functionality than necessary, while at the same time letting me play with lots of electronic components and microcontrollers in the process.

I went through several prototypes during the development of YAMC. A couple of different microcontrollers, a couple different kinds of LEDs, switches, power connectors, potentiometers, etc. I even at one point tried to include a microphone into the design.

So I eventually scaled back, decided on a final set of functionality (the three modes you see in the cube now), and limited the electronics. Mostly to cap things like “cost”.

That said, I really hope you make one of these and enjoy it. It was a lot of fun to design, a labor of love to force myself to complete, and a real challenge to stay “focused” on.

Full instructions on how to build, photos, etc., can be found on my blog: http://trippingthenerdcurmudgeonly.blogspot.com/

Printing:
The Diffuser should be printed in clear (natural) PLA, and the Cube Top, Cube Base, and Knob should be printed in whatever color you desire. I highly suggest printing the Cube top with the built-in supports, and printing all pieces at 100% infill to keep "light leakage" to a minimum.

author: cdeschrun

title: Silica Gel Case / Spool End Cap for Vacuum Sealing Filament

description.text:
This is to be used in conjunction with my filament spool wall holders here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:923016

I store filament on my wall, but recently I've been concerned about moisture causing printing issues. (See here: http://3dprintingforbeginners.com/how-to-store-3d-printing-filament/ )

Inspired by the above post, I decided to vacuum-wrap my filament. But how to vacuum-wrap AND hang them?

That's where this Spool Endcap comes in. You put the filament and this piece inside the bag, then pull the back side of the vacuum bag through the middle hole. Now when you suck out the air, there will be a central hole in which you can hang the filament.

The piece doubles as a silica gel holder. Pour the desiccant through the hole on the bottom and then snap on the cap.

Here is what you will need:

  1. My filament spool wall holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:923016

  2. Medium-sized Ziploc space bags: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0009VCB4S

  3. Color changing silica gel, such as this: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00967K0MG

One case of silica gel is enough for at least 3 spool end caps. When the silica changes from orange to green, simple recharge by taking out the silica, placing on a pan, and heating in the oven at 250 degrees for a few hours.

Recommended print settings: .2mm layer height, 15 percent or more infill, no support structures.

Now you can keep your filament moisture-free while still hanging!

author: airforce

title: Five-Cent Hammer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When you have a hammer, all of your problems look like nails. When your problem is a nail, you're kind of screwed if you don't have a hammer.

Unless you have five cents and a 3D printer! This simple model lets you quickly print a five-cent "hammer" that is small enough to fit in your pocket. Pause the printer to insert your coins when appropriate. The demo models are for holding five US pennies; if you want to use some other kind of currency, then make your own cheap hammer by clicking the "Open in Customizer" button.

WARNING #1: When you add the coins, make absolutely sure that the top coin does not extend above the current printed material; if your printer catches on the coin then either your model or your printer could be damaged.

WARNING #2: Although this "hammer" is safer than using a drinking glass, you could actually hurt your fingers if they slipped off the tool and onto the nail you are driving into the wall. Please use caution and always use a Real Hammer if you have serious work to do.

CHALLENGE: Anyone want to make a remix of this that has a handle (but is still Customizable)?

This is my entry for Week 2 of the atartanian vs. mathgrrl design battle! atartanian's Week 2 offering is an absolutely incredible Customizable Diorama. So maybe people can use my cheap-ass hammer to hang up one of atartanian's beautiful dioramas... :)

Read more about this design at Hacktastic.

title: Itty Bitty Dual Extruder Mount for RepRap Wilson TS/II, Prusa i3 rework

description.text:
Simple plate which adapts from the Makerfarm X-Carriage to the RepRap Wilson TS X-Carriage. It's an openscad model with a lot of variables than can be tweaked, but I wrote this to get it done quickly (limited time available on a friend's printer to print my printer) and the code needs cleanup. My primary goal was to be able to use the itty bitty dual flex extruder.

Can be adjusted to any other X-Carriage hole spacing. The default is 23mm center to center for all four holes, which matches the Wilson TS, Wilson II, and Prusa i3 rework (at least). This does work on the Wilson II but only before the rack and pinion bed leveling mechanism was added -- I do intend to try and make an adapter plate that is compatible with the new Wilson II x-carriage eventually (but don't let that stop you from contributing one ;) ).

Version 4 is 31mm shorter than previous versions. I was able to countersink the holes for mounting the x-shelf of the extruder and have them overlap the x-carriage mount. It seems to be more stable as well. I fixed a few minor alignment problems, cleaned up the openscad source a tiny bit, and improved hole tolerances so in theory they won't need to be cleaned up at all now.

Git repository with sources: http://git.hcoop.net/?p=clinton/3d-models.git

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Wilson TS

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Support for countersunk holes on the bottom of the plate.

abs at 40% infill with a 1mm perimeter seems sufficiently strong without adding too much weight to the x-carriage.

Use a soldering iron to press a pair of M4 Hex Nuts into the hex not slots for attaching to the x-carriage.

The parts included with the Clough42 kit should be sufficient for mounting the itty bitty dual flex extruder (or any of the itty bitty extruders).

comments.text: Great tip "Use a soldering iron to press a pair of M4 Hex Nuts into the hex not slots". No more burning myself with a lighter.

Beach Inspirations

A sandy beach is essentially an infinite, maleable, instantly-erasable, reshape-able plane; a whiteboard on which patterns can be created, modified, erased, and washed away. Relationships can be formed and destroyed with a shovel, a bucket, a hand, or a wave. And the space available for exploration is vast, practically infinite.

A beach can naturally be filled with dunes, with children, with sun. But can math fill a beach? Can small shapes, ones we can hold in the palm of our hands, be made to cover wide sandy planes? Let's find out together by exploring tessellations.

The tessellation is a type of infinite pattern that completely covers a plane in one or more shapes. The squares of a checkerboard, carried out to infinity, are one basic type of tessellation, as are the cells of a honeycomb. These patterns, made of basic shapes (squares and hexagons, respectively), can both be carried out to infinitely, filling all the space on a plane, much as the sandy shore covers the water's edge.

But checkerboards and beehives are simple tessellations; each uses only one shape, in one scale, with no rotations; the mathematics of covering a plane run much deeper. In this thing, I aim to develop a basic set of sand sculpting tools to explore 2D geometry, and tessellations in particular, using sand.

Current Status

-July 25 - Parameterized the mold-making via OpenSCAD. Now, any 2D geometric shape that's describable can be turned into a sand-mold, and all molds will have common, adjustable properties for iteration. Published Project.

  • July 24 - Changed name of project to Castellations. Couldn't pass up the Portmanteau
  • July 23 - Start of project and first upload - a set of square sand stencils with varying profiles, to see if any are suitable for making shapes in sand

Shapes

-Square
-Equilateral Triangle
-Regular Hexagon
-Regular Octagon
-Rhombus (60/120 Degree)
-Rhombus (30/150 Degree)

Future Goals/Problems to Solve

  • Make these bits into, well, castles! They're no fun if they're not castles...
  • What vertical profile is best for engraving a design into sand? Are stamps or cutters better/more durable?
  • Is there a way to enforce only edge-to-edge tessellations through design? (Notching, labeling?)
  • Find a way to connect stencils/stamps together along edges, to create more complicated shapes.
  • 3D Tessellations?
  • Put the name/angle of each shape on a stamp?

The tessellation tiles are crafted programmatically in OpenSCAD, then combined into a single print using the MakerbotDesktop software.

Unfortunately, OpenSCAD doesn't quite have the math acument to programmatically determine the verticies of a regular polygon, so the basic shapes are created manually in code. A wrapper function then ensures that all finished prints have similar physical parameters (height, depth, labeling, etc.)

Round 2, in the epic matchup!

mathgrrl vs. atartanian

1 design per week, winner take all!

The Challenge is evolving!

If you were following along last week, you saw that both of our designs were remixes. We both knew that we had to bring original designs to the table for this weeks challenge.

My entry for this week is a Customizable Diorama. It's modular so you can design all sorts of different scenes and mix them together. What starts as a lovely woodland scene with rabbits and trees quickly evolves into an Alien invasion, then just as quickly Super Intelligent Androids appear to fend off the otherworldly threat!

Click here to make your own!

Your imagination (and drawing ability) are the only limits to the awesome scenes you can create.

The more people draw and share their scenes, the more combinatory possibilities there are! Factorial growth!

Each pane allows you to add 3 hand-drawn shapes which can be multiplied, rotated, scaled and moved around.

The diorama is fully customizable, down to the size and number of panels that the frame can hold. You could even make a frame that can hold a ton of really thin panels and recreate the cross sections of an animal or other shape!

(100 internet points to the first person who makes a blue whale cross section diorama)

Again, I'd like to thank mathgrrl for getting me excited to contribute more to Thingiverse. I can't resist a little friendly competition :)

In the coming weeks, you can expect more customizers including some old ideas that never made it into the light of day and some new ideas that have been stewing!

Check out mathgrrl's awesome entry for this week and let us know what you think in the comments! Got some design you want to see us tackle? Post that in the comments too!

comments.text: Though it seemed a tie at first glance, I simply must award this week's point to atartanian for the only reason that he managed to spark an idea in one of my own designs.

author: Prognosis

description.text:
Heavy Duty Z Motor Mount; to reduce wobble.

I am Very happy using this mod.

uses standard threaded rod and nut, plus I added 2/ 15mm long brass bushes with 8mmID (Inside Diameter) and 12mmOD.

I have also made it to work with a MOORE & WRIGHT 0-15MM MICROMETER HEAD MW310-15 0.01MM INCREMENTS 5MM ANVIL.

comments.text:
Hi dear maker:
This modification looks strong and very capable but I think that you may get even better Z axis precision movements if you eliminates the flexible coupling. If your are taking all the Z axis weight with the Z motor, I really think that it works a lot better without this kind of coupling. The big problem comes from the screw thread precision. I am always thinking on changing my Z axis screw for a better one to solve this problem. If the screw is the original one, ok you may no use a solid coupling.
comments.author: MRiutort

description.text:
THIS IS AN UNTESTED PROTOTYPE: Inspect fit clearances before printing.

This is a 3D printed harddrive bay for standard 3.5in harddrives. It uses bare drives without the need for trays/rails. The door actuates a lever arm to unseat the drive for removal. It fits in a CD drive bay and mounts the same way. SATA hotswap capability requires a motherboard with AHCI.

Required hardware (lengths are not strict. Check files for exact hole lengths):
7 M2x15
2 M2x10~12
1 M3x35
CD drive mounting screws (M3)

Future plans:
If I can get dimensions for a cheap SATA 22-pin cable (like this one ebay.com/itm/Male-to-Female-7-15-Pin-Serial-ATA-SATA-Data-power-combo-extension-Cable-FO-/291369269696) I would integrate it into the rear plate. This would make the connectors slide together more reliably and with less tweaking of the dimensions.

comments.text: Is the data & power cable secure somewhere in the model.
comments.author: conorm125

comments.text: They go into the recess on the rear plate. I would recommend getting a combined 15+7 pin SATA power+data cable and changing the recess to accept that. Aligning two separate cables would be tricky.
